objectives: Use gustar to express likes and dislikes
Talk about hobbies and free time
Express opinions with me gusta/no me gusta

dialogue_blocks.speaker: Sara
dialogue_blocks.text: ¿Qué te gusta hacer en tu tiempo libre?
dialogue_blocks.translation: What do you like to do in your free time?
dialogue_blocks.ipa: [ke te ˈɡusta aˈseɾ en tu ˈtjempo ˈliβɾe]

dialogue_blocks.speaker: Tomás
dialogue_blocks.text: Me gusta mucho escuchar música y salir con amigos.
dialogue_blocks.translation: I really like listening to music and going out with friends.
dialogue_blocks.ipa: [me ˈɡusta ˈmutʃo eskuˈtʃaɾ ˈmusika i saˈliɾ kon aˈmiɣos]

dialogue_blocks.speaker: Tomás
dialogue_blocks.text: Sí, me encanta el fútbol, pero no me gusta el béisbol.
dialogue_blocks.translation: Yes, I love football, but I don't like baseball.
dialogue_blocks.ipa: [ˈsi me enˈkanta el ˈfutβol ˈpeɾo no me ˈɡusta el ˈbejsβol]

dialogue_blocks.speaker: Sara
dialogue_blocks.text: ¿Y qué tipo de música te gusta?
dialogue_blocks.translation: And what kind of music do you like?
dialogue_blocks.ipa: [i ke ˈtipo ðe ˈmusika te ˈɡusta]

dialogue_blocks.speaker: Tomás
dialogue_blocks.text: Me gusta el rock y la música regional mexicana. ¿Y a ti?
dialogue_blocks.translation: I like rock and regional Mexican music. And you?
dialogue_blocks.ipa: [me ˈɡusta el ˈrok i la ˈmusika reˈxjonal mexiˈkana ‖ i a ˈti]
dialogue_blocks.context: Stating music preference and asking back

dialogue_blocks.speaker: Sara
dialogue_blocks.text: A mí me encanta el pop. No me gusta nada el reggaeton.
dialogue_blocks.translation: I love pop. I don't like reggaeton at all.
dialogue_blocks.ipa: [a ˈmi me enˈkanta el ˈpop ‖ no me ˈɡusta ˈnaða el reɣeˈton]

dialogue_blocks.speaker: Tomás
dialogue_blocks.text: ¡Qué curioso! A mí me gusta muchísimo el reggaeton.
dialogue_blocks.translation: How interesting! I like reggaeton a lot.
dialogue_blocks.ipa: [ke kuˈɾjoso ‖ a ˈmi me ˈɡusta mutʃiˈsimo el reɣeˈton]

srs_flashcards.back: I don't like it at all
What do you like to do?
to read / to cook / to dance

exercises.instruction: Escoge la forma correcta de gustar
exercises.question: A ella ___ los libros de ciencia ficción.

feedback.correct: ¡Correcto! 'Gustar' agrees with the subject (libros = plural → gustan), not the person.
feedback.incorrect: 'Gustar' is tricky — it agrees with what is liked, not who likes it. Libros is plural → gustan.

exercises.instruction: Une la expresión con su fuerza

pairs.english: I don't like it at all

dialogue.speaker: A
dialogue.text: A mí no me _____ nada. Prefiero comer.

speaking_rubric.title: Mis gustos (My likes)
speaking_rubric.scenario: You meet someone at a party. Share 3 things you love and 1 thing you dislike.
speaking_rubric.prompt: Di tres cosas que te gustan y una que no te gusta.

sample_response.text: Me encanta el fútbol y me gusta mucho cocinar. También me gusta leer. No me gusta nada madrugar.
sample_response.ipa: [me enˈkanta el ˈfutβol i me ˈɡusta ˈmutʃo koθiˈnaɾ ‖ tamˈbjen me ˈɡusta leˈeɾ ‖ no me ˈɡusta ˈnaða maðɾuˈɡaɾ]

cultural_notes.formality: 'Gustar' conversations are a staple of social bonding in Mexico. Music, food, sport and family are the most common topics. Don't be surprised if preferences lead to playful debate — Mexicans enjoy spirited discussion.
cultural_notes.gestures: Thumbs up = like, thumbs down = dislike. Chefs kiss gesture (kissing fingertips) indicates something is delicious or excellent.
cultural_notes.regional_variations: Fútbol means soccer everywhere. In Mexico, 'lucha libre' (wrestling) is a beloved cultural pastime. Telenovelas and regional music are genuinely popular topics of preference discussion.
